required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Quadruple Fortified Salt in Improving Hemoglobin Levels Among Anemic Women of Reproductive Age (18-49 Years) in Rural Low Resource Setting

brief_summary.textblock: Anaemia is the world leading cause of disability and is responsible for about more than 115,000 maternal deaths and 591,000 perinatal deaths per year, of which 3/4 occur in Africa and Asia. Despite the fact that there are several causes of anemia, the most important causes are due to micronutrients deficiency, namely iron, Folic acid and Vitamin B12. Low intakes of these micronutrients consequently affect a woman's health, pregnancy outcome and the nutritional status of breast-fed children. With these in mind we wish to test the effectiveness of salt fortified with these four micronutrients (Iodine, Iron, Folic acid and vitamin B12) in raising the Hemoglobin levels among the non-pregnant and non-lactating women of reproductive age.

detailed_description.textblock: Anaemia is the low level of Haemoglobin based on the location. As per WHO a woman is termed anaemic if has HB <11g/dl but in high attitude is =<13g/dl

primary_outcome.description: After 10months use of quadruple fortified salt we expect the HB to rise by at least 50% as compared to those who used iodised salt

secondary_outcome.description: The quadruple fortified salt is expected to replenish the iron store 100% after 10 months use of QFS

intervention.intervention_name: Iodised salt with Iron, Folic acid and Vitamin B12
intervention.description: Fortified salt with either Iron and Iodine only or Fortified salt with Iodine, iron, Folic acid and Vitamin B12 compared with standard Iodized salt

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult with relative low haemoglobin (Hb level 8g/dl to 13g/dl)
- Able to eat food cooked with salt
- Able to give consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Planning to become pregnant within the study period,
- chronically ill,
- have haematological diseases during study time,
- restricted to use salt in food
